paragraphs.text:
%md
## Welcome to the Realtime Syslog Analytics tutorial, powered by Juju.
### In this live tutorial we will demonstrate three phases of a big data solution:
#### 1. Data Ingestion: rsyslog -> Flume-Syslog -> Flume-HDFS
#### 2. Data Processing: Spark
#### 3. Data Visualization: SparkSQL+Zeppelin

result.msg:
Welcome to the Realtime Syslog Analytics tutorial, powered by Juju.

In this live tutorial we will demonstrate three phases of a big data solution:

1. Data Ingestion: rsyslog -> Flume-Syslog -> Flume-HDFS

2. Data Processing: Spark

3. Data Visualization: SparkSQL+Zeppelin

paragraphs.title: Generate Data and Verify Ingestion
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# Generate syslog messages by trying to ssh to the namenode unit.
# This will likely result in a 'publickey denied' error, but it will
# be enough to trigger a syslog event on the namenode.
MASTER=`grep namenode-0 /etc/hosts | awk '{print $1}'`
for i in `seq 1 10`;
do
  ssh -oStrictHostKeyChecking=no $MASTER uptime >/dev/null 2>&1
  sleep 1
done

# Check if Flume has collected and sent the syslog messages to HDFS.
# If no output is seen from this command, wait a few minutes and try
# again. The amount of time between Flume ingesting the event and it
# being available in HDFS is controlled by the 'roll_interval'
# configuration option in the flume-hdfs charm.
hadoop fs -ls -R /user/flume/flume-syslog | tail

result.msg:
drwxr-xr-x   - flume supergroup          0 2016-03-23 17:44 /user/flume/flume-syslog/2016-03-23
-rw-r--r--   3 flume supergroup       1700 2016-03-23 17:04 /user/flume/flume-syslog/2016-03-23/FlumeData.1458752459536.txt
-rw-r--r--   3 flume supergroup       2738 2016-03-23 17:09 /user/flume/flume-syslog/2016-03-23/FlumeData.1458752863145.txt

paragraphs.title: Simple Data Processing with Scala
paragraphs.text:
// Output the number of sshd syslog events
sc.textFile("/user/flume/flume-syslog/*/*.txt").filter(line => line.contains("sshd")).count()

paragraphs.title: Data processing to enable future queries

result.msg:
import scala.util.Try
reSystemLog: scala.util.matching.Regex = ^\<\d+\>([A-Za-z0-9, ]+\d{2}:\d{2}:\d{2}(?:\.\d{3})?)\s+(\S+)\s+([^\[]+)\[(\d+)\]\s*:?\s*(.*)
defined class SyslogMessage
lines: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[String] = /user/flume/flume-syslog/*/*.txt MapPartitionsRDD[114] at textFile at <console>:41
events: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [timestamp: string, host: string, process: string, pid: int, message: string]

paragraphs.title: Data Visualization
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
select process, count(1) value
from syslog
group by process 
order by process

paragraphs.title: Data Visualization
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
select host, count(1) value
from syslog
group by host

paragraphs.title: Data Visualization
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
select process, timestamp, message
from syslog
order by timestamp desc
